Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an ALMA Beamformer for Ultra High Resolution VLBI and High Frequency Phased Array Science
Award.AbstractNarration: The ability of astronomers to detect fine structure details in distant objects depends upon the angular resolution obtainable from their telescopes and instruments. Angular resolution is related to the wavelength at which the observations are made (the smaller the wavelength, the higher the resolution that can be achieved) and also to the diameter of the observing objective (the larger the objective, the higher the resolution). In most cases the observing objective is the size of the telescope's primary mirror. But when multiple telescopes are used simultaneously and their beams are combined the objective size becomes the baseline distance between the telescopes used. For several decades, radio astronomers have taken advantage of large baselines by coordinating observations between radio telescopes on different continents in a technique termed Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI). This technique has enabled radio astronomers (who work at quite long wavelengths compared to that of visual light) to achieve angular resolutions that rival, and in some cases surpass, the kinds of resolutions available to optical astronomers. Dr. Sheperd Doeleman of the MIT Haystack Observatory has been successfully increasing VLBI resolution by using shorter wavelengths and he now wants to add VLBI capability to the new Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) that is now becoming operational in northern Chile. By adding ALMA to the VLBI network the angular resolution will be improved by a factor of two and the sensitivity of the ensemble of telescopes will increase by a factor of ten. Technically, this will involve combining the beams from up to 66 telescopes in ALMA into one phased and coherent signal that can then be used as one VLBI station. This new capability will enable scientists to use VLBI to study the environment around and very close to Black Holes like the one at the center of our own Milky Way Galaxy and another in a nearby very massive galaxy. The results of these investigations are likely to lead to new understanding of the physics in strong gravitational fields and will provide new tests for the theory of General Relativity. This work will be made possible through an award from the National Science Foundation's Major Research Instrumentation program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The technique of Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) enables the highest resolution measurements of astronomical sources presently achievable. In VLBI, signals from an astronomical source are recorded at telescopes spread around the globe, together with ultra-precise timing information derived from a device called a hydrogen maser. The resulting signals are then aligned (to compensate for the slightly different arrival times of the cosmic signal at each telescope) and combined using a specialized supercomputer called a VLBI correlator, resulting in measurements with an equivalent resolving power equivalent of telescope as large as the Earth. 

VLBI techniques have been used for decades to study centimeter wavelength radio emission from astronomical objects. However the extension of this technique to millimeter wavelengths allows achieving still higher angular resolution---a few tens of microarcseconds. Such a resolution would be sufficient to allow counting the stitches on a baseball from 8000 miles away. Millimeter wavelength observations also enable unique types of scientific measurements because they are less susceptible to scattering and absorption toward certain types of sources, such as the black hole at the center of the Milky Way.

While the technique of VLBI at millimeter-wavelengths holds great promise, to date its scientific applications have been limited by the small number of telescopes currently equipped for millimeter VLBI, as well as the small collecting area of existing telescopes. These factors severely limit sensitivity and make it difficult or impossible to reconstruct images of sources.

The ALMA Phasing Project (APP) was conceived to harnass the power of the world's most sensitive millimeter observatory, the Atacama Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), for VLBI. This capability is expected to enable groundbreaking new science, including the ability to obtain the first ever images of the black hole at the center of the Milky Way and the galaxy M87 on Event Horizon scales, allowing important new tests of General Relativity. Additional science applications will include the study of the launch and collimation of astrophysical jets from active galactic nuclei, the study of astrophysical masers (the radio wavelength equivalent of lasers) in star-forming regions and the atmospheres of evolved, mass-losing stars, and searches for new pulsars near the central regions of  our Galaxy.

ALMA comprises 66 individual radio telescopes spread across a portion of the Atacama desert of northern Chile. Ordinarily, ALMA's dishes operate as an interferometer, and information from different pairs of antennas within the array are used to construct images of astronomical sources. Although highly sensitive, these images have 100 times lower angular resolution than can be achieved with VLBI.

The current award therefore equipped ALMA with the hardware and software necessary to function as the world's most sensitive millimeter VLBI station. Work included the technology to synchronize or "phase" the signals from the individual antennas and the means to add them together to create the equivalent sensitivity of a single giant antenna. 

As part of the ALMA Phasing Project, a hydrogen maser was installed at ALMA to provide the precision timing information required for VLBI. Modifications were made to ALMA's correlator (the supercomputer at its heart) to enable production of a summed antenna signal and to reformat the data as required for VLBI applications.  The resulting "sum" signal is sent through an optical fiber link system that was built and installed at ALMA by the APP team to transport the data stream from the ALMA correlator to a bank of specialized ultra high-speed recorders installed at the ALMA operations center roughly 15 miles away.

Other major aspects of this program included the development of a new ALMA VLBI observing mode and the specialized software necessary to "phase up" the signals from the individual ALMA antennas. This latter process must be performed continuously throughout an observation, as perturbations in the Earth's atmosphere (mainly caused by variations in water vapor in the troposphere) would otherwise decorrelate the signals from the different ALMA antennas, resulting in a steep loss in sensitivity. The final stages of the project entailed Commissioning and Science Verification, a rigorous process of end-to-end testing of the entire phasing system using on-sky measurements. 

The completion of this project has resulted in a fully functioning phasing system being delivered to ALMA. The addition of phased ALMA to existing networks of VLBI antennas around the globe provides a boost in sensitivity of an order of magnitude. In addition, it enhances the resolving power of VLBI arrays in the north-south direction and provides valuable new information that will enable reconstructing ultra-high-resolution images of sources. ALMA is therefore now able to contribute its enormous sensitivity to global arrays of radio telescopes that are poised to make the highest resolution astronomical images ever achieved. 

The first ever VLBI science observations with phased ALMA were conducted in April of 2017 by teams of scientists from around the world. Analysis of the resulting data is currently underway.
